author: Bethan Holt
title: Viola Davis swaps heels for trainers after winning her Oscar for Best Supporting Actress
text:
Viola Davis swaps heels for trainers after winning her Oscar for Best Supporting Actress Viola Davis in Armani at the Oscars Credit: Jordan Strauss Bethan Holt , Digital fashion editor 27 February 2017 • 5:09am 
B est Supporting Actress winner Viola Davis looked fabulously glamorous at tonight's Oscars, taking to the red carpet in lipstick-red draped, halterneck gown which was custom-made for her by Armani and chunky gold jewellery by Niwaka. The finishing touch? A co-ordinating pair of sky-high satin platforms by Stuart Weitzman. 
But once the Fences actress had given her emotional acceptance speech, she soon changed into a more comfortable pair of platform trainers. And who can blame her? 
Davis's stylist, Elizabeth Stewart, posted an photo from backstage at the awards which showed the Weitzman heels being swapped for an equally sassy, but more comfortable, pair of trainer-platforms by Los Angeles-based shoe brand, Y R U. It's a move which women the world over will relate to. Viola Davis with stylist Jenny Brunt changing into her comfy platforms backstage Credit: Instagram/elizabethstewart1 
"With brilliant team member @jennybrunt1 backstage at the ready with @yrushoes platforms for comfort," Stewart wrote. "Thanks @stuartweitzman for carrying Viola to the win!" 
T he 51 year-old actress was soon celebrating her Oscar win in comfort- and style- with her husband, Julius Tennon, and son, Genesis. 
With an evening of celebrations and after-parties ahead of her, Davis's decision to change into something a little more comfortable once her onstage moment was over seems only sensible and a very clever piece of forward planning. 
With her win, Davis became the first black actor to be awarded Tony, Emmy and Academy awards. In her acceptance speech, she paid tribute to August Wilson, the playwright who originally wrote Fences . Viola Davis with her award- and newly comfy shoes- backstage at the Oscars Credit: LUCAS JACKSON/ Reuters 
“People ask me all the time, what kind of stories do you want to tell, Viola? And I say, exhume those bodies, exhume those stories, the stories of the people who dreamed... I became an artist, and thank god I did, because we are the only profession that celebrates what it means to live a life. So here’s to August Wilson, who exhumed and exalted the ordinary people.” 
M eanwhile, Stewart spoke earlier this week of Davis's no-nonsense approach to her red carpet style. “The interest in what Viola’s wearing is way greater than the attention she pays to it,” she told Vanity Fair . And while many Hollywood actresses expend serious time and energy poring over outfit possibilities and collaborating on the style they will present to the world, Davis appears to be impressively efficient about the process. “I would say I’m like the dentist to her,” Stewart added, explaining that fittings with Davis were usually over within five minutes. Viola Davis and husband Julius Tennon Credit: Getty 
D espite the impressive speediness of her dressing decisions, Davis has carved out a reputation for her simple yet powerful looks which have always been vividly colourful but devoid of too much glitz. "Color, clean, strong, bold" were the buzzwords Stewart listed as being integral to any Davis look. 
Tonight, we can add "comfy" to that list too. The trainer-swap is a refreshing move from Davis in a world where "no pain, no gain" is the usual mantra.
